newsitem.title: USA: US Southeast power mixed in thin pre-holiday trade.
newsitem.headline: US Southeast power mixed in thin pre-holiday trade.

text.p: Spot electricity prices in the southeastern U.S. were notionally mixed Tuesday in very light trade ahead of the Christmas holiday, sources said.

Firm, peak power prices in the northern part of the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) territory for Thursday were assessed in the $14.00-16.00 per megawatt hour (MWh) range, as compared with Monday's $9.50-10.50 trading range.
Firm, off-peak electricity in northern TVA was notionally assessed at $8.00-9.00, but no deals could be confirmed done.
At the Georgia/Florida border, prices for firm, peak electricity in 16 hour blocks for Thursday delivery were still in the $17.00-18.00 range, with deals confirmed done at $17.75.
Firm, off-peak power for Thursday at the Ga./Fla. border was still notionally assessed at $9.00.

Temperatures in the Southeast are expected to drop to eight to 12 degrees below normal on Wednesday but then moderate into the weekend. This colder-than-normal weather is forecast to stretch into northern Florida on Wednesday and Thursday.
Like power prices, natural gas spot values in south Texas fell by at least five cents today into the $3.70s to about $3.80 per million British thermal units.
Separately, Virginia Power's 781 megawatt (MW) Surry 2 nuclear unit resumed full power production after synchronizing to the grid on Monday.
